captions.text:
We've written a letter,
trying to explain things...
It is Hebrew, from the Talmud.

It says:
"Whoever saves one life, saves the world entire. "
I could have got more out.

I could have got more.
I don't know.

Oskar, there are 1,100 people who are
alive because of you. Look at them.
I threw away so much money.

There will be generations
because of what you did.

title: Schindler's List (8/9) Movie CLIP - He Who Saves One Life Saves the World Entire (1993) HD

comments.text:

ten movies list and that's saying something because I hate depressing films 
and would always regret wasting my time on them. But this was really worth 
my time﻿

comments.author: Deputy Ben Dover

comments.text:
The quote is mistranslated. It should be, ..."saves a world entire." The 
Talmud (where this quote came from) doesn't suggest that saving a life 
saves the entire world. It means that in saving a life you are saving 
someone who has hopes, dreams, fears, disappointments, memories. Each 
person is in themselves their own world. To save a life is to save that 
entire world.﻿
comments.author: Mrpastry909

comments.author: jutubaeh

comments.text:
Whoever destroys a soul, it is considered as if he destroyed an entire 
world. And whoever saves a life, it is considered as if he saved an entire 
world. — Mishnah Sanhedrin 4:9; Babylonian Talmud, Tractate Sanhedrin 37a.
comments.author: Eli Lederberger

comments.text:
+Mrpastry909  I think the mistranslation has more truth to it. Let's think 
for a moment, pick one person at random, if something had happened and they 
hadn't lived, what would be different? Somebody like Martin Luther King 
Jr., Mother Teresa, Joan of Arc, Sheriff Buford Pusser, Dr. Jonas Salk, 
Mary McLeod Bethune, the mother who gave birth to any great leader, 
activist, etc., anybody who had a vital impact on changing the history of 
their town, their state, their country, or even the entire world. Now 
consider who will be the future teachers, healers, leaders, one person in 
turn impacts other people's lives, maybe one, maybe 10, maybe 100, maybe 
thousands, each person, added or subtracted, changes the impact of the 
world's future and history. It DOES make sense. To take any of them away 
would be a great tragedy, to save any of them MIGHT just mean saving the 
world entire.

comments.author: ndrthrdr1

+The Friendly Activist
I want my bacon! My scrambled eggs! My barbecued steak! My hamburgers with

comments.author: morro190

comments.text:
+OnCatNip I truly understand that this is new thinking for most people, and 
I can honestly say that I did anticipate a response like that. But please 
realise that we do not need to eat meat, dairy, or eggs to survive. There 
is no nutrient in them that we can not get from a cleaner, healthier, 
cruelty free, plant source. Our physiology does not point towards that of 
an animal designed to eat meat (like a lion etc.) Our teeth (no we do not 
have flesh tearing canines) are identical to that of frugivors, our saliva, 
stomach, intestines, hands and finger nails, the speed we run etc is not 
that of a carnivore etc. Please check out my channel for more info, and 
would be happy to answer any question you have about health/animal 
rights/environmental impact of humans eating animal products.
comments.author: The Friendly Activist

comments.text:
+The Friendly Activist im sorry dude but comparing the holocaust to killing 
animals is retarded, we kill animals for meat. It's not like the nazis 
killed, jews blacks and all kinds of people for food right? we kill animals 
because we have to, not because we enjoy it or want to do it.
comments.author: OnCatNip

comments.text:
Let me ask you this...With the justification you are using, basing it on 
"consiousness", you are saying that it is justified to "humanely" kill 
people with amnesia, memory loss, and other mental problems, including 
autism, down syndrome, etc... since they "can't piece together situations" 
? (which animals clearly do). "humane slaughter" is a LIE. It would be like 
being married for 20years, and treating your partner like a king/queen all 
their life... but one night while they are sleeping, taking a blade and 
cutting their head off. Technically they didn't know a thing, but is that 
not still murder? The only twisted thing, is people, such as yourself, 
justifying murder by the intelligence of the victim. If that were the case, 
it would be okay to murder babies and disabled people.
comments.author: The Friendly Activist

comments.text:
The difference lies at consciousness, livestock are not able to comprehend 
situations or put them together, they are not conscious as we are, they 
still feel pain however, it is not justified to allow an animal to suffer, 
but to kill it humanely is another story. Comparing the killing of 
livestock to the holocaust is twisted.
comments.author: TheMacoLion

comments.text:
+Ali "The Friendly Activist" Tabrizi  While I enjoy a variety of fruits and 
vegatables, i am not willing to give up meat. And even if i were willing, i 
can't afford a purely fruit and vegatable diet. Thats part of the reason i 
hunt. By killing a deer, a moose, and a bear, a year I am able to keep my 
freezer stocked for the year, thus negating greatly a huge chunk of my 
budgetary concerns.
comments.author: morro190

comments.text:
"But when it comes to food, we have to eat."... that is not true at all +
morro190. I appreciate that you have taken the time to reply elaborately, 
but humans do not need meat to survive. You can take a look at the 
documentary 'Forks Over Knives" for scientific data and studies. There is 
literally nothing in meat, dairy, and eggs, that we can't get from plants 
in a healthier package.
comments.author: The Friendly Activist

comments.text:
+Ali "The Friendly Activist" Tabrizi
 First off im fine with you not killing animals. If you want to be a vegan, 
thats fine and theres nothing wrong with it. To clarify, i think animals 
should be treated as well as we can. But when it comes to food, we have to 
eat. I work on a ranch and have worked on many farms.

When dealing with cattle, me and my fellow ranch hands treat them well, 
take care of them when their sick, and make sure that their comfortable. If 
they go to the slaughter house my hope is that they'll be well treated 
until their slaughtered, and when they are, its as quick and painless as 
possible.

The fact is animals aren't humans, even if we are a part of the animal 
kingdom. It is morally wrong to hurt an animal for no reason in my books, 
but killing animals for food is not. Animals kill animals and eat them. 
We're just doing what is natural, the only diffrence is we've got the 
ability to breed animals for food instead of just hunting them, and grow 
crops for food.

As for my hunting, lets say i decide not to kill a deer. Whats going to 
happen to that deer is its going to grow old, get slow, and be mauled to 
death by another animal and eaten anyway. When i kill it, its instant and 
painless, when another animal kills it, its gonna be a lot more painful.

Am I saying that the way that animals are treated when their being grown in 
slaughterhouses doesn't need to be looked at? Not at all. But at the end of 
the day, comparing that to the holocaust or any genocide is disrespectful 
to the people who suffered and died.
comments.author: morro190

comments.text:
Wait, +morro190  you kill animals... Yet I disgust you because I don't kill 
animals, and say that animal farming is exactly like the holocaust?  You 
can not morally justify what we are doing to these animals. There is no 
excuse for it. All exploitation of beings, idiotically justified by the 
excuse that they are "lesser" or "different" from us (which is what the 
nazi's said about the jews, blacks, etc,) is yet another example of 
discrimination and murder. If you can find reason to justify what we are 
doing to the animals, (including what you are doing by shooting animals) I 
would be happy to hear you out. But before you type just think "what if 
these animals were human."
comments.author: The Friendly Activist

comments.text:
+Ali "The Friendly Activist" Tabrizi
 Ok, some people are dicks to animals. Your still a deranged retard for 
equating it to the holocaust. I hunt animals all the time for food, and i 
live by the rule 1 bullet 1 kill. Meaning that the first time i shoot at an 
animal it should die instantly. God you hippies disgust me.

comments.text:
This is sad, I feel bad for the INNOCENT Jewish people who had to go 
through this. But I also feel bad for the 5 million others killed who don't

complete control over what we are taught and hear in the media.. I also

(probably because they don't know). It isn't taught in school, there aren't 
movies made about it. All because the people who were doing the killing 
were Jewish and the victims were not Jewish. They also refuse to teach it 
because it might make people anti-Semitic. Well if the truth makes them 
that way then so be it. The truth should still be taught. I think most 
Americans would be understanding that it wasn't the Jewish people who did 
it but the Jewish leaders. Just like the German people didn't do the 
holocaust, it was the German leaders. Both truths should be taught so both 
sides can learn from their mistakes.﻿

comments.author: Pavel Sachkovsky

comments.text:
It's not literal you idiot. The point of it is that all goodness in the 
world is ultimately comprised of individual actions. The holocaust was the 
most terrible thing to ever befall humanity - but without individual people 
like Oscar Schindler, we would have never emerged from it. 
And for accuracy, the actual full quote is: "Whoever destroys a soul, it is 
considered as if he destroyed an entire world. And whoever saves a life, it 
is considered as if he saved an entire world."
comments.author: Arkady

comments.text:
In Israel there is a saying "He who saves one life, counts as saving an 
entire world." That's the proper translation. The translation in the movie 
a bit fails...

comments.author: Backup One

comments.text:
If one life isn't worth something to someone, no matter how many people,

comments.author: Grumbel Bumbel

comments.text:
Well technically, if one person disappears before his/her time, I guess the 
world changes drastically and exponentially (something like Butterfly 
effect). The endless possibilities and impact his/her choices could have 
made are forever lost and banished by reducing him/her to none, whether by 
him/her being taken his/her life by others or himself/herself. Also, doing 
good inspires others to do the same, making a link between people to do 
good and be kind and genuine towards others. Lastly, I feel like we are all 
a world on our own, pulled in some togetherness of sort, with the way we 
can imagine and dream of various things, existent and not. Those are the 
reasons I feel the sentiment: "He who saves one life saves the world 
entire" true and inspiring. It is just my opinion and I could be wrong :) I 
hope this helps, take care :D
comments.author: Milan Jolic

comments.author: Martintheauthor

comments.text:
+Martintheauthor The Talmud itself isn't sacred, although it's often 
referenced as a guide for how to interpret the Tanakh. It's a collection of 
debates over how Scripture should be read, and how the archaic laws should 
be adapted for modern life. That being said, it's over a thousand years old 
now, so "modern" is a relative term.
comments.author: Griffin Greenberg

comments.text:
“Schindler’s List”
September 1939 the German forces defected the Polish Army. Jews were 
ordered to register family members and relocated to major cities. More than 
10,000 Jews arrive there daily. March 20, 1941, deadline for entering the 
Ghetto, Eddict 44/91 established a closed Jewish district south of the 
Vistula River. All Jews from Krakow were forced from their homes and 
required to crowd into sixteen square blocks. The Jewish people thought it 
was a refuge until later they would be sent to the furnaces and their 
bodies would be burned and laid in huge graves.
The Jewish council comprised of 24 elected Jews were personally responsible 
for carrying out the orders of the regime in Krakow, such as drawing up 
lists for work details, food, and housing.
Liquidation of the Ghetto occurred March 13, 1943. Jews sick in hospitals 
were poisoned right before the German’s came in and started shooting them 
as they lay in their beds, they knew they were going to die. So many were 
hiding, children were many even hid in the outside latrines in fear of 
their lives. Men were told to stand in a line where they were shot from 
front to back. Both women and men clothes were removed and ran naked, heads 
were shaved before they would enter the doors where they were gassed to 
death. Chujowa Gorka, April, 1944 Department D orders goeth to exhume and 
incinerate the bodies of more than 10,000 Jews who were killed at Plaszow 
at the Krakow Ghetto Massacre. 
Schindler made a list of over 800 Jews which he wanted to save to work in 
his factory. The men made it safely to his hometown, but the women were 
sent to another concentration camp at Auschwitz. When Schindler got wind of 
this he drove there to try to get his Jews returned to him, and he did. He 
made laws that there would be no executions, no interfering with factory 
workers or German soldiers would be imprisoned. For the seven months the 
factory was operational, Schindler’s Brinnlitz Munitions Factory was a 
model of non-production. During this same period he spent millions of 
Reichmarks to sustain his workers and bribe Reich officials.
Then the day came when United States President Eisenhower declared the war 
was over. The German war was at an end, so Schindler announced to the 
Jewish people who survived after midnight they would be free. He also told 
them that he would be hunted because he used slave labor to make money. 
Many tears were shed by him because he wished he had saved more Jews.
Amon Goeth was arrested while a patient in a sanitarium at Bad Tolz and was 
hanged by the neck until he was dead at Krakow for crimes against humanity.
Oscar Schindler failed at his marriage and several businesses after the 
war. In 1958 he was declared a righteous person by the council of Yad 
Vashem in Jerusalem, and invited to plant a tree in the Avenue of the 
Righteous.﻿
comments.author: Linda Newsom

comments.text:
This scene and so many more in Schindler's List always reduces me to tears. 
Not just because of the total horror associated with the Holocaust and it's 
architects but of the sheer humanity exhibited by Schindler in 
circumstances where it could easily have led to his death at the hands of 
the Nazis. Never was the Hebrew proverb more appropriate "He who saves one 
life, saves the world entire"﻿
